[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting Exploration gives +1 [ICON_MOVES] Movement for Naval units and +1 Sight for Naval combat units. Unlocks building the Louvre. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting all policies allows you to see Hidden Antiquity Sites. It also allows the purchase of Great Admirals with [ICON_PEACE] Faith starting in the Industrial Era. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]-1% [ICON_HEALTH] Empire Health for each policy adopted in this branch.[ENDCOLOR]

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Rationalism[ENDCOLOR] improves the ability to use and generate [ICON_RESEARCH] Science. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting Rationalism will grant +10% [ICON_RESEARCH] Science while the empire is [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happy. Unlocks building the Porcelain Tower. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Adopting all Policies in the Rationalism tree will grant a free Technology. It also allows the purchase of Great Scientists with [ICON_PEACE] Faith starting in the Industrial Era. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]+1% [ICON_HEALTH] Empire Health for each policy adopted in this branch.[ENDCOLOR]

[ICON_HEALTH] Health determines the likelihood that a city will suffer [ICON_PLAGUE] Plagues. Positive Health is converted into [ICON_FOOD] Food each turn.

A City's [ICON_HEALTH] Health is based on access to fresh water (Aqueducts can provide fresh water), local resources, population, and completed buildings. City health is magnified by the Empire's Health Multiplier (see [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Empire Health[ENDCOLOR]). [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE]Healthy, non-stagnant cities convert surplus Health ([ICON_PLUS][ICON_HEALTH]) into [ICON_FOOD] Food each turn. Unhealthy cities are much more likely to spawn, propagate and suffer from [ICON_PLAGUE] Plagues. [ICON_PLAGUE] Plagues always begin in cities with the lowest global [ICON_HEALTH] Health. Plagues may spread to nearby cities, cross international borders, and propagate to distant cities over land and sea routes. Plagued cities and diseased units will recover after several turns or when the outbreak has ended. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Plague Effects[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Cities may lose 1[ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen per turn while plagued; Cities cannot die of plague. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][ICON_CAPITAL] Capitals will never decrease below 3[ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Building an Academy with a Great Scientist instantly cures that player's plagued cities. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Cities regain fewer hitpoints each turn if attacked while plagued. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Cities have a chance to spread the plague to other cities each turn (based on Difficulty, Era, Map Size). [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Units in and near plagued cities will take damage each turn; they cannot die of disease. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Units in and near plagued cities can get the [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]Disease Promotion[ENDCOLOR], which greatly reduces their defensive abilities. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Plague Spread[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]World size, game speed, difficulty, and current era all effect how fast and how far plagues will spread. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]In general, plagues spread fastest in the Medieval Era and slower in later eras. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]In general, plagues spread further in later eras, but are mostly local in the Ancient and Classical Eras. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Open Borders and International Trade Routes will speed the spread of plagues into foreign lands. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Civs that are Influential or Dominant on another civ will speed the spread of plagues into their lands. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Cities connected to the local trade network are more likely to spread plagues in friendly lands. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Healthy cities are less likely to contract or spread plagues. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Diseased units near a city will increase the chance that plague will spread to that city. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]If your civilization has ever been plagued, your spies (not Diplomats) have a small chance to unleash a plague when placed in foreign cities.
